Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award provides travel funds enabling students to attend the 15th IEEE International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC) to be held in Orlando, FL on November 3-5, 2019. IISWC is the premier forum for understanding and characterization of workloads that run on all types of computing systems. Topics of interest include but are not limited to characterization of applications in domains; emerging workloads and architectures; implications of workloads in design issues; benchmark creation and evaluation; characterization of OS/VMM, middleware and library behavior; measurement tools and techniques.

The award is to provide travel support for around 30 U.S.-based students attending this event. The selection process will give priority to US citizens and permanent residents, with special consideration to members of under-represented groups and participants from universities that do not have a strong tradition in the topical areas covered in the conference, in order to expand the scope of the conference participation. Students attending this workshop will benefit from the rich interactions and networking/mentoring opportunities afforded by their presence at the event.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported students to participate in the 2019 International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC). That includes travel financial support for a total of 15 student conference attendees. The project widely advertised the available support in order to attract women and underrepresented minority groups, through postings on programming languages, systems, computer architecture web-sites and mailing lists. As a result, among these student attendees, two students are from underrepresented groups. This project also supported five students from abroad, while ten of the student attendees supported are from universities in the US.

In addition, this project also supported three student attendees, who are not an author/presenter of a paper at the conference. As a results, these students will not be able to attend the conference without the support of this project. Therefore, this project effectively strengthened the conference as a result of greater attendance that this travel support enabled.

This project also disseminates the intellectual knowledge learned by the student attendees by attending the conference. In particular, each student wrote an essay about their experience, interactions with other conference attendees, and knowledge learned from attending the conference. Furthermore, based on the essays, the students, who received the travel support, have personally benefit from the opportunity to interact with peers and experts, as well as establish connections that will help their professional career.

Finally, by focusing on students, this project helped foster the mentoring of subsequent generations of computer systems researchers.
